children.value: “It is a set of well defined steps, which are followed to solve a problem”
Determine best profit for thief in a Knapsack
Help salesperson travel all cities with minimal cost to meet monthly targets
There are 5 key characteristics of an algorithm:-
Every step is meaningful and unambiguous for the reader.

children.html: xxx
xxx

children.value: Every algorithm must have finite number of steps.
An algorithm must accept zero or more inputs.
It must produce atleast one output.
It must be followed easily, even with pen and paper.
It is the most effective way to represent an algorithm.
It is in normal english language.
It is written as a sequence of steps.
Psuedo code for making a Tea

children.label: Psuedo code for making a Tea

children.html: 34\frac{3}{4}43​
12\frac{1}{2}21​
12\frac{1}{2}21​

children.value: Light the stove to medium flame and place vessel.

children.html: 34\frac{3}{4}43​

children.value: Add tea leaves, crushed ginger and sugar.
Wait till water begins to boil.
Once the solution begins to boil, and comes to the brim of the vessel, turn off the flame.
Now, filter the tea from vessel to cup.
This is how we write Pseudo Code of a problem!
Actually, we have discussed only way of making a tea.
Here, we have allocated our ingredients before, then prepared the tea.
So, it make our process faster, but used up too many resources such as:
3 tea spoons for tea leaves and sugar
Instead of using 2 cups, we can use just 1 cup to put water first, then, milk.
We can solve the same approach the other way, where we will access ingredients and resources when required, no pre-allocations!
Now, this will save our resources, but increase time spent to make a tea, because there will be extra time to get resources and ingredients.
Similarly, for other approaches, to make the same tea, we analyse their performance based on their:
And, this is what we study in this subject, when we go for analysis part of an algorithm.
It is the time taken by an algorithm to solve our problem.
It is the space taken by algorithm to solve a problem.
Sometimes, we compare bunch of algorithms together, some are slower, some are faster, while other takes almost same time and space.

children.value: Lies between Upper bound and Lower bound.
It is a linear data structure, i.e. elements are accessed one after another, like we have place plates one over another in wedding.
It has only end for storing (Push) and removing (Pop) an element.
It operates on LIFO (Last In First Out) principle.
TOP - It is a pointer to the topmost element of the stack.
IN - It is the input direction of an element on the top of the stack.
OUT - It is the output direction of an element from the top of the stack.
(MAX) associated with it, which shows the maximum elements it can store.
It refers to storing element on the top of the stack.
During push, TOP get incremented by 1, and we store element at that location, with:
It refers to removing element from the top of the stack.
During pop, we simply decrement TOP by 1
It refers to view the TOP element of stack, with:
It checks whether stack is empty or not.

if (TOP == -1) then
    return 1; // i.e. stack is empty
else
    return 0; // i.e. stack is not empty
It checks whether stack is full or not.

MAX is the limit of the stack.

if (TOP == MAX) then
    return 1; // i.e. stack is full
else
    return 0; // i.e. stack is not full
It is a linear data structure, i.e. elements are accessed one after another, like we have place plates one over another in wedding.
REAR is for storing elements, and FRONT is for removing elements. (It’s a choice, we can change it)
It operates on FIFO (First In First Out) principle.
associated with it, which is the maximum element it can store in it.
It is a pointer to the rear of the Queue.
It gets incremented by 1, when we add an element to Queue.
It stops, when REAR becomes equal to Capacity.
It is a pointer to the front of the Queue.
It gets incremented by 1, when we remove an element from Queue.
It stops, when FRONT becomes equal to REAR.
It refers to storing element to the REAR of the Queue.
During enqueue, REAR get incremented by 1, and we store element at that location, with:
It refers to removing element from the FRONT of the Queue.
During dequeue, we simply increment FRONT by 1
It refers to view the FRONT element of Queue, with:
It refers to view the REAR element of Queue, with:
It checks whether Queue is empty or not.
if FRONT > REAR, then Queue is empty.

if (FRONT > REAR) then
    return 1; // i.e. Queue is empty
else
    return 0; // i.e. Queue is not empty
It checks whether Queue is full or not.
If REAR is equal to Capacity, then Queue if full.

CAPACITY is the limit of the stack.

if (REAR == CAPACITY) then
    return 1; // i.e. queue is full
else
    return 0; // i.e. queue is not full
It is a non-linear data structure.
It is designed as a parent-child relationship, so it is a
- It is a storage unit in tree, which contains values and pointer to predecessor node & successor nodes.
- It is a link between 2 nodes, as A & B are connected by an edge.
- An immediate predecessor (i.e. previous node) of a node, as C is Parent node of F.
- An immediate successor (i.e. next node) of a node, as F is Child node of C.
- It is the node which has no further child node, as F is a Leaf node.
- A tree which is a subset of given tree, see the diagram above.
- The topmost node which is the predessor of all nodes.
Number of edges from root to a given node
For example, Depth of node E is 2, in diagram above.
It is the total number of edges in the tree.
If number of nodes in a tree are

numberofedges,e=n−1number\hspace{2px} of\hspace{2px} edges, e = n - 1numberofedges,e=n−1

children.value: For example, there are 7 nodes, and 6 edges in the tree above.
It is the longest path in the tree, i.e. number of edges from root node to leaf nodes is the highest.
For example, in the tree above, height of the tree is 2.
It is number of children a node has.
For example, Node B has degree of 2, while leaf nodes has degree of 0.
It is a non-linear data structure.
Unlike other data structures, there is no hard and fast rule about what must be the first node, placement of node and its traversal.
Any node can participate a graph at a time.
But, there is only one rule that:
we must reach all nodes connected to given node using the given edge only once.
So, keep record of all vertices and edges, we have a set of vertices as

children.html: VVV

children.value: and a set of edges as

children.html: EEE
GGG
G=(V,E) G = (V, E) G=(V,E)

children.value: where, V is set of vertices (nodes), and E is the set of edges
There is no rule to add us as a user, every account has equal importance.
But, when we are a part of an university, we are under an hierarchy (tree data structure), like student to Class Representative to Class Teacher to HOD and so on.
